item.title: MA259 Notes
item.description: These are some summarised notes for MA259. I tried my best :) Just like any other module, this module can be split into theoretical and computational. Obviously the theoretical parts are important as well, but in my opinion having a computational intuition helps see the big picture easier. Here, I only summarise the computational part of the module. For the proofs, you will need to look at the lecture notes themselves, but I don’t think they will be terribly important.

item.title: Jacobi Quartics
item.description: This is a short note on Jacobi quartics and its relationship with elliptic curves. Definition An elliptic curve in Jacobi quartic form is a curve of the form $J_a: y^2 = x^4 + 2ax^2 + 1$, where $\det(J)$, which is some multiple of $a^2 - 1$ here, is nonzero. This model of elliptic curves is important as it provides quicker point arithmetic. We shall prove that the curve $J_a$ is birationally equivalent to $E_a: 2v^2 = u^3 - 2au^2 + (a^2 - 1)u$.

item.title: Modular Forms
item.description: I have decided to take on the topic of Modular Forms. I don’t intend to dive too in depth into the topic, since it is obviously a rich theory and has many prerequisites. However, I will try to get a basic understanding of what is it about and what the theory tries to answer. References: Kilford (Book), Conrad (Notes), Conrad (Videos), Borcherds (Videos). Update time: Apr 24, 2023 (Modular forms, $q$-expansion, Eisenstein Series) Apr 29, 2023 (?

item.title: Bernoulli Polynomials
item.description: Please note that $p$ does not denote a prime, but instead usually an integer $p \geq 0$. Existing lemmas Definition by recurrence: $$ B_n = 1 - \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \binom{n}{k} \frac{B_k}{n + 1 - k} $$ $$ B_n(x) = \sum_{k = 0}^n \binom{n}{k} B_{n - k}x^k $$ Faulhaber’s theorem: $$ \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} k^p = \sum_{i = 0}^p B_i \binom{p + 1}{i} \frac{n^{p + 1 - i}}{p + 1} $$

item.title: Finite Realm of Random (498 points, 4 solves)
item.description: Introduction Our team Black Bauhinia participated in the idekCTF 2023 which spans two days. Finite Realm of Random was an interesting math / crypto puzzle. In the end, only 3 teams solved it the intended way, and we were the second. Problem Statement Description: I took a flag, and shuffled it. I took a part, and randomized it. I took the bits and pieces, and scattered them across the field. Now, only an haphazard mess remains.
